Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978) 808-1932

==============================

If you are interested in participating in this event be sure to read the entire trip listing before you RSVP - then be sure to answer the questions during the RSVP process (even if you have answered them before).

While the objective of this trip is to enjoy ourselves as we climb, your safety, and the safety of the others in our group, is the most important thing. If you underestimate the demands of this trip, or overestimate your skills and abilities, you may put yourself and/or others in the group at risk – consider this before you decide to participate.

==============================

Wildcat Mountain (4,422 feet), located within the Carter-Moriah Range, offers dramatic, close-up views of Mount Washington and the Presidential Range from its northeastern shoulder, Mount Hight. Wildcat's D Peak (4,070 feet), home to Wildcat Ski Area, is considered an independent 4,000-footer. While we will use the hiking trails to get to the top, we will use the ski trails to get to the bottom.

Click here to see a video compilation of previous Random SledFest events.

While I have hiked these peaks before, I did all of my current research using the AMC's White Mountain Guide, a trail map, and the Internet. The links below provide an overview of where we will be going and include topographic maps of the area. You should become familiar with this information since you are ultimately responsible for your own safety.

Click here for more information about Wildcat A from Peakbagger.com

Click here for more information about Wildcat D from Peakbagger.com

Click here for trail conditions near Wildcat from TrailsNH.com

If dangerous weather conditions cancel this event we will simply go elsewhere and climb to a different summit. I will notify confirmed participants of any planned changes a day or two ahead of time. The plan will be to hike somewhere in the White Mountains.

This is an official “sledfest event”, which means if you don’t bring a sled you will miss out on the fun. The most popular choices are:

Click here for more information about the Zipfy Sled

Click here for more information about the Slidy Sled

You are encouraged to wear a helmet as if you were skiing the trails. Be sure to have a way to secure your sled to your pack for the snow shoe up and your snow shoes to your pack for the sled down.

This is a "no dogs" hike.

==============================

Trip Summary

On this trip we will hike the Nineteen Mile Brook trail to the AMC’s Carter Notch Hut where we will stop for a snack/lunch before beginning the steep climb up Wildcat Ridge Trail - first to Wildcat A, then along the protected ridge to Wildcat B, C, D, and E. We will then sled down the ski trails after the area closes at 4:00 PM to our cars in the parking lot below.

On this slow to moderate pace trip we will hike about 8.1 miles and climb about 3,700 feet (for perspective the top floor of the Empire State Building is about 1,250 feet). It should take an average hiker about 6 hours 45 minute to complete this hike during the summer – this estimate does not include time for snacks/lunch or breaks to layer/delayer or change snow shoes/crampons. This hike is considered Intermediate because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

We start as a group, stay as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. If you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us or want to head off on your own, this isn't the trip for you. Likewise, this trip isn't for you if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you or want us to go on without you. Fatigue and other unexpected conditions can alter our plans.

If you have ANY questions about your ability to participate in and complete this entire trip please contact me.

==============================

Weather

It is winter in the mountains - expect cold and windy conditions. Temperatures drop 3-5 degrees for every 1,000 feet of elevation gained.

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this hike - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants a day or two before this event.

Click here for the current weather forecast for this trip.

Mountain weather is subject to rapid changes and extreme conditions. We will assess travel and weather conditions during the hike and make changes to our planned trip as necessary.

==============================

Clothing and Equipment

Below is a list describing the minimum required clothing and equipment to participate in this event. DO NOT rely on others to have extra clothing or equipment to share with you once we are out on the trails. Bring enough to keep you warm and protect you from the wind in case we have to stop/wait in one place for a prolonged period of time.

Footwear: Insulated winter hiking boots. Snowshoes and crampons are mandatory (you can bring microspikes but only as a back-up). Be sure to have a way to attach these to your pack.

Clothing: Dress in layers to easily regulate body temperature. Wear synthetic shirt/pants and bring a fleece jacket/wool sweater. Winter hat. Face shield/balaclava. Winter mittens/gloves. ABSOLUTELY NO COTTON.

Outerwear: Insulated jacket with hood. Waterproof/windproof rain shell with hood.

Food and Water: High-energy snacks, food for lunch, enough water to stay properly hydrated during the trip. Hydration bladders may freeze during winter - bottles with insulating sleeves work best.

Other Essential Gear: Map and compass. Plastic whistle. Headlamp with two sets of spare batteries (lithium work best in cold temperatures). Chemical hand/foot warmers. Personal first aid kit. An emergency space blanket (e.g. mylar). Small pocket knife or multi-purpose tool. Toilet kit (e.g. hand sanitizer, toilet paper and a zip-lock bag to pack out your used personal hygiene items). Sunscreen. Lip balm. Sunglasses. Waterproof cover for your pack. Extra hat, mittens/gloves, and socks.

Optional Items: Waterproof/windproof pants. Waterproof gaiters. Trekking poles. Camera. Ice axe.

You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip.

I am not certified or trained in wilderness first aid. You will need to bring any medications or medical supplies that you may need during the trip.

==============================

Directions

We will begin this hike by meeting at the Northeast corner (nearest Route 16) of the Wildcat Ski Area parking lot at 9:30 AM. According to Google Maps this meeting spot is about 188 miles from Boston and it should take about 3 hours 20 minutes to drive there.

Click here for driving directions to the meeting spot

We will then leave a few cars in the lot and drive further north to the Nineteen Mile Brook Trail parking area where we will start our trip.

==============================
